good_at:
- She has a lot of ideas but can't express them all fluently.
- Needs to practice her listening skills more, most of the time Coach has to write down the questions.
- Here is an example how to answer questions about opinion and options.
Question: Your boss is considering offering you a 2-year business trip in the US and you'll earn a lot more than now but you could only go alone, without any of your family members. What would you decide to do, your family or your job?
Ms.Yen's ideas:  my son is too young, i have to take care of my family
Sample answer from Coach: In this context, you might say that there is no easy answer to this dilemma. You have to weigh the pros and cons of both options and decide what is best for you and your family in the long run. You have to consider your values, goals and priorities. You have to talk to your family and see how they feel about it. You have to trust your intuition and follow your heart.
Wow, this is such a tough situation. I would be very happy if my boss offered me a 2-year business trip in the US. This would be a great opportunity for me to learn more, to explore the culture and working environment in the US, and maybe to earn a higher salary. However, I have a son and he is too young. I need to take care of him as well as my husband and my parents. So I would have to decline this opportunity. I would choose my family over my career.

- She is able to keep going and is willing to give long answers, but her speed is slow and coherence is occasionally lost through hesitation while she searches for words and ideas.

need_to_improve:
1. Pronunciation: 
- process /ˈprɑːses/
- encourage /ɪnˈkɜːrɪdʒ/
2. Language Use: 
- I'm working in PUMA → I'm working for PUMA
Work in means to work inside a place or an industry. For example, I work in a restaurant. I work in finance.
Work for means to work as an employee of a person or a company. For example, I work for Microsoft. I work for Mr. Smith.
Work on means to work on a specific task or project. For example, I work on a project. I work on improving my English.
- In the weekend... → At/on the weekend...
- They will work with us in 6 months. → They will work with us for 6 months.
The difference is in the meaning of the prepositions for and in. For means for a period of time. In means after a period of time. The first sentence means that they will work with us for a period of 6 months. The second sentence means that they will start working with us after 6 months.
3. New words: 
- exhausted (v): kiệt sức, mệt lử

Describing your job:
- I work at + company name
- I work in + department/field
- I work with + when you're a part of the team or representative of the organization

- I am responsible for + V-ing

2. Language Use: 
Ms.Phuong has shown some weaknesses in her English speaking skills during the conversation. Here are some mistakes:
- ... to help other person. → ... to help others/ that person/ other people.
When asked about their feelings after helping someone, she responded in the present tense, whereas the question was in the past tense:
- I feel... → I felt... (Q: How did you feel when you helped someone?)
When asked about how parents teach children the importance of helping others, she provided limited ideas and her answers throughout the conversation were generally brief.
- It's very importance to teach children to help others. They can feel better and they can learn the ways to help others.  (Q: How do parents teach children the importance of helping others?)
- I can busy with the other things and I cannot do that. → I may be busy doing something and I don't have time to help that person, so I refuse.
- The same me. → It's the same to me.
- When I was a student, I went to the pagoda to cook on the first month and the middle month. → ... on full moon days and on fiftheen days (ngày rằm)

- It can be punished... → It (Media outlets) should be punished... (We should use "should" insteading of "can". False information should be punished, not only because it can be very serious if media outlets give false information, but because it undermines public trust and can have far-reaching consequences.)

For instance, at first, she says that she updates news from Tik Tok, Facebook, and on TV. However, she later indicates that the information from these sites is not trustworthy.
